High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz46GVtcBGa

“It’s not going to happen,” Mr Gundlach says, definitively. “People like to complain, they like to say what’s wrong but then when it comes down to actually pulling the lever they sit there and they say, ‘what exactly am I doing here, what is going to happen?’ The devil you know is better than the devil you don’t know. Look at what happened with Scotland. People aren’t going to pull a lever for Brexit, so I don’t even think that’s worth considering in the present time.”

PM

Anyway, on the broader state of affairs

PM

Have some Neil Mellor

PM

BNY

11:10 am
PM

As we argued last week, it is still too early to say whether there has been a shift in attitude towards the USD in Washington; but events over the past two months have had a familiar feel to them and the market is clearly questioning whether the Federal Reserve is wedded to a two-hike schedule any more than it was to the four-hike schedule proposed in December. So, the market is in thrall to US monetary policy, and just how the ECB responds to this is far from clear.

PM

Global monetary policy and USD based flows have dominated market activity for some time and almost to the exclusion of all else. A real acid test in this regard is how the Brazilian Bovespa and BRL performs - the two having performed strongly since late January despite a steady deterioration in Brazilian economic fundamentals and the growing prospect of President Roussef's impeachment. However, developments in the oil market are enlightening: oil and commodity prices have performed strongly year-to-date, and the former in particular has done so in the face of a global supply glut with every prospect of a top up from Iranian output. And despite suffering a marked sell-off post-Doha (which left a rather daunting technical picture in its wake), NYMEX futures prices are back pretty much where they started the weekend. It would seem that for central banks presiding over commodity-based economies, the quest for more competitive currencies will remain elusive; but they will certainly not be alone in that regard.

PM

This brings us to the ECB meeting on Thursday. As we see it, it is difficult to rebuff the view that what meagre recovery the Euro-zone has managed to eke out is largely down to the ECB's 'currency policy' and its boost to exporters; and hence, the EUR's resurgence amidst uncertainty surrounding the Fed's plans emphasises the clear limits to what Mr Draghi can achieve. The ECB president, we believe, arrived at similar conclusions some time ago. Mr Draghi stated at Jackson Hole in 2014 that "since 2010 the Euro-zone has suffered from fiscal policy being less available and effective... Thus, it would be helpful for the overall stance of policy if fiscal policy could play a greater role alongside monetary policy, and I believe there is scope for this". And although German finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble claimed at the time that Mr Draghi had been "over interpreted", Draghi's comments a month later sounded remarkably similar: he told Lithuanian business daily Verslo Zinios , "Governments should not unravel the progress made in fiscal consolidation, but use any leeway to make fiscal policies more growth-friendly." And in early October, Mr Draghi observed, ra

11:10 am
PM

Sorry, missed the end of that line

PM

ther more pointedly, that "monetary policy should not be the only game in town". No grey areas there.

PM

Yet such petitions (which have also been voiced by Jack Lew and more recently by the IMF) have fallen on deaf ears and will continue to do so owing to Germany's 'Schuldenbrems' or balanced budget law, the crux of the Euro-zone's tight fiscal stance and its external counterpart, a current account surplus (of circa 2.3% of GDP). Whilst fiscal prudence is Germany's prerogative as a sovereign nation, in the Euro-zone it is in a unique position as principal creditor and most dominant economy, and so its budget surplus enforces a 'bad equilibrium' upon neighbours who must reduce spending to eliminate their bi-lateral deficits given Germany's refusal to boost demand for their exports. So, just what else the ECB could possibly do and what lengths it should go to under such circumstances is far from clear, particularly at a time when criticism is growing for what it has already done. All in all then, the recriminations amongst G20 nations look set to continue as monetary policy will remain the principle tool of a global economic policy response that continues to fall short in its quest for stability.

BE

Let me get some Barclays to sum things up.

11:19 am
BE

FY16 adjusted PBT expectations per Bloomberg have trended lower since the 1H16 results from £59.9m in November 2015 to £53.3m last week, moving us from positioned below consensus to above. On the call, management confirmed that the additional FX impact was approaching £2m, suggesting a c. £51m outturn for the year. To be clear, this unexpected impact has arisen from a large amount of billings issued at the beginning of March being retranslated lower at the close of the period, i.e. a transactional impact. The only other detail in the statement was that a £4m exceptional expense has been incurred in order to implement further cost savings. In any case, with the EPC project spending environment remaining very challenged, the focus is now shifting to the outlook for FY17. We currently forecast a 2.5% organic reduction in revenues for this year.

BE

No commentary on the FY17 outlook was provided in the statement, however, management expanded on the call. In terms of revenue, they accepted that revenue growth will be hard to come by, but they are expecting a positive rather than negative development. We expect a c. 4% FX tailwind to FY17 at current rates, which likely will be the driver of this. The cost saving measures should save c. £8m a year, twice the exceptional cost, but will be offset by cost inflation resulting in a broadly flat cost base. Therefore, this commentary would support an outlook of broadly flat profitability from the pre-FX £53m level. Bloomberg consensus is currently at £57.2m. Phasing in this year should be similar to FY16.

In terms of extra detail on the year just closed, rental and annual fees were largely as expected. There was a sequential improvement in initial licence fees, but we anticipate a similarly tough year-on-year result as the -18% in the first half. Brazil unsurprisingly remained weak with a better performance in North America and a stable EMEA result, held back by FX. Overall the company considers the oil & gas environment to have stabilised somewhat, while the focus remains also on the continued expansion into new verticals.

BE

(@Mo: deleted. Please don't.)

11:19 am
BE

We remain Equal Weight balancing the challenges in the oil and gas backdrop with the upside risk of a further approach. Equally, a cash return was planned as part of the Schneider deal and, in the absence of further M&A targets, this could reemerge as an option. Our price target equates to 17x our current CY17E EPS (cash adjusted), having downgraded our outer year EPS estimates by c. 5% in our note last week. FY results are scheduled for 24th May.

PM

(But now Mouselet's comment lacks context)

BE

(I think it's just as useful when standing alone.)

11:20 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Trading "broadly in line": Aveva has released a trading update for its FY
ending March 2016. The company stated that revenues and adj. PBT were
“broadly in line" with market expectations. However, it flagged that FX asset
translation (esp. $ weakness at year-end) would impact adj. PBT negatively. We
believe that consensus was for revenues of £203m and adj. PBT of £53m, in
line with MSe revenue for FY16 of £202m and adj.PBT of £54m.
Further cost cutting suggests little pick-up in sight: Aveva also announced
that it has embarked on a further round of cost cutting. The company expects
an exceptional cost of £4m to implement this – with part of the £4m expensed
in the FY16 numbers. The additional cost cutting suggests to us that there is
still little sign of pick-up in Aveva's core markets – not a surprise given the
continued weakness in the oil price.
Is "in line" enough? We have traditionally found valuations floors for
software companies using EV/recurring – and seen levels of c. 4x as attractive.
Aveva's valuation on this basis is slightly more complex as a larger proportion
of “recurring” (c.60%) comes from more volatile rental revenues rather than
maintenance revenues. Even if we take all the rental revenues as recurring,
Aveva is trading on c.5x CY17e recurring – some way off our floor. Applying a
20% haircut to rental revenues gives an EV/recurring value of c.6x CY17e. On
traditional measures Aveva is trading on 21x P/E CY17e for a business that we
expect to show muted growth. As a result, while "“in line" may be enough to
see the shares bounce for a software company trading on floor multiples, we
think the current multiple is more demanding. In addition, the new round of
cost cutting suggests an upturn is not yet in sight on the top line. We expect a
muted reaction today and remain UW.

BE

So that's Aveva.

Here's Cazenove.

BE

Primark performance as expected; LFL sales marginally negative yoy.
Sales in the first half were +7% yoy on a constant currency basis (+5%
reported), in-line with guidance at the pre-close stage for +7.5%. LFL sales
in H1 fell by “less than 1%”, in-line with previous comments for a broadly
flat performance. LFL growth was hampered by unhelpfully warm weather
ahead of Christmas. France LFL sales were strong and the negative impact
from new store openings on LFL sales in Germany and the Netherlands
eased (also previously flagged). FY16 space growth is expected to be 1.4m
sq ft, in-line with previous guidance. Primark operating profit was £313m in
the half. This is -1% yoy on a constant currency basis (-3% reported) and
2% ahead of consensus for £306m (range £297m to £322m). This result
represents an operating margin of 11.7% (H115 12.6%). The key reason for
the yoy decline is the well understood impact of the dollar strength on the
gross margin (although this was managed well by the group, with mitigation
from both better buying and markdown). In H116 Primark operating profit
represented 64% of the group result.

11:34 am
BE

- Shortly before going into closed season, ABF issued a detailed trading update
in which it predicted that adjusted operating profit would show "some
progress", whilst adjusted EPS would be "slightly lower". Today's results are
very much in line with this guidance, and just slightly ahead of consensus.
Adjusted Pre Tax Profit has come in at £466m (versus consensus of £454m),
with adjusted operating profit up 3% at £486m (consensus £480m), and
adjusted EPS flat at 46.1p (consensus 44.3p)
- Primark's operating profit has come in at £313m (versus consensus of
£306m) - down 3% on last year, despite a 7.5% increasing in selling space,
principally as a result of adverse FX movements during the period.
- Although this is a lengthy statement, there does not appear to be much 'new
news' here. The comment that is probably likely to attract the most attention
here is that "early trading at our two stores in the US has been encouraging,
with very positive customer feedback", though this is really only a reiteration of
what the company has said previously.
- We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but the statement makes
clear that it expects "only a marginal decline" in adjusted EPS for the full year,
which is consistent with the guidance it gave at the pre close statement. We
would not, therefore, expect much movement in consensus forecasts today.
According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for FY 2015/16e
Adjusted Pre Tax Profits of £1027m (100.7p EPS)
- Based on current consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, ABF is
trading on 31.5x Cal 2016 earnings, 16.5x EBITDA with a 1.1% Dividend Yield.
This compares with a European General Retail sector trading on 22.5x, 13.4x
and 2.8% respectively

BE

And Credit Suisse ......

BE

...... because it's always enjoyable to quote Charlie Mills on fast-fashion trends.

11:35 am
BE

■ The beat versus our estimate is almost entirely the Primark margin
which is only off 90bps where we had -110bps. The gross impact of
course was much greater (400bps?) but significant procurement and
freight savings have offset most of this. Furthermore the group has had
rather less mark-downs and stock levels were kept tight. The margin
decline for the full year is expected to be no worse than seen at the half
way mark. Worth noting this margin decline includes the cost of the
USA infrastructure buildout.
■ Overall Primark's like-for-likes were small down (less than 1%) with
strong sales in Ireland and France, modest increases in Spain offset by
a small (1%?) decline in the UK and cannibalisation in Germany from
new store openings albeit at much reduced levels.
■ The USA is described as "encouraging" but still only has 2 stores.
Footfall and sales densities are increasing steadily.
■ The food businesses saw a few pluses and minuses but are all pretty
much where we expected. Ingredients as expected is the standout
performer. Sugar looks to be on the turn and is set for a much better
new year as higher prices feed through the P&L.
■ We raise our EPS estimates by just over 1% to 101.2p and our price
target by £1. Rating remains Outperform

A brief but reassuring IMS.

BE

Barclays incoming.

BE

This morning’s Q1 IMS print was light in detail, but provided a reiteration of the FY guide and noted trading during Q1 has been in line with expectations. We trust the CMD, which starts at 9:15, will be the start of a confidence-building process, enabling investors to shift focus away from the next quarters volatile Civil AM print (noting a healthy 7% organic growth rate in Q1) towards a structurally supportive growth story over the medium term at a compelling valuation of 11x FY17E P/E with a 4% dividend yield.

11:51 am
BE

· Civil aerospace revenue grew 6% organically (within which organic AM grew 7%, a positive number after an enduring softness) which should please many. We expect today’s CMD to provide much greater colour around how the CSS initiative, designed to recapture and better understand Civil AM dynamics, underpins this print and future performance.

· Group revenue growth of 1% on an organic basis is consistent with previously announced expectations that revenue and earnings will be weighted towards the H2 following the atypical phasing in 2015.

· Military revenue grew 1% organically while energy weakness persisted, as expected, resulting in a 15% organic decline for the period.

· The Group made good progress against the cost reduction plans detailed in the full-year results announcement in February, and is confident of achieving the targeted headcount reduction of 400 by the end of H1.

BE

BE

 ZPG buys Property Software Group: This morning ZPG announced the acquisition of Property Software Group (PSG), the
market leading provider of software solutions to UK real estate agencies, for £75m, 12x FY1 EV/EBITDA. The acquisition is
expected to be adj EBITDA and adj EPS accretive in the first full financial year following completion (CSe +8%).
 We see the acquisition as a strategic positive: The acquisition of PSG enables ZPG to offer agents a comprehensive "endto-
end" solution for property professionals allowing them to manage every stage of the process from marketing a property
through to exchange. This will give agents much greater visibility throughout the process and will, in our view, make ZPG's
offering differentiated from Rightmove's.
 Energy switching fuelling growth: The group also announced that thanks to a "strong performance" at uSwitch the group
expects full year 2016 results to be "towards the higher end of market expectations". This implies a 4% u/l upgrade to cons
FY16 adj EBITDA estimates.
 We now sit +13% ahead of cons for FY17: We make wholesale changes to our u/l assumptions, significantly raising
uSwitch expectations and significantly lowering property expectations. We then also incorporate the PSG acquisition.
Overall we raise FY16 and FY17 adj EBITDA by +3.3% and +1% respectively. We sit +6/+13% ahead of cons FY16/17 for
adj EBITDA.
 Catalysts: HY16 results are due 25 May 2016.
 Valuation: ZPG currently trades on a 21.6x FY16e P/E, falling to 17.0x for FY17e. This compares against the European
Internet space trading on 23.1x falling to 19.8x. We see these discounts as too great and reiterate ZPG as our top call in the
European Online media space. We are raising our Target Price to 340p (from 290p).

BE

What's new?
Zoopla has announced the proposed acquisition of the Property Software Group (PSG),
a leading provider of software solutions to property professionals. PSG's products are
used in over 8,000 agency branches, providing day-to-day management of inventory,
marketing and communications, diary management, chain progression, business
reporting tools and financial processes. The group earned revenues of c.£15.9m in the
year ended 31 March 2016, and c.£5.1m adjusted EBITDA, with 84% recurring revenue
and a customer retention rate in excess of 97%. Management expects c.20% EBITDA
growth from the acquired business. The purchase price is £75m in total (£47m initial)
funded through internal cash resources and new debt. Completion is expected within 60
business days.
The Canaccord Genuity view
This acquisition looks smart - Zoopla is acquiring a high-margin SaaS business which
is clearly integrated into its customers' day-to-day activities. It will enable Zoopla to
deepen its relationships with its customer base, and extend its influence along the value
chain. Management expects c.20% earnings growth from PSG as it expands its cloudbased
service and grows its leading market share, as well as through the launch of
new products including Move It and My Property File. The combined group will have a
relationship with c.18,000 agents, a c.40% increase from current levels, and the deal
should help to strengthen the group's competitive position.
uSwitch is also proving its mettle within the group, and we think it will benefit from a
number of long-term growth drivers. Energy industry switching volumes have increased
sharply following a number of price cuts in recent months, which has led management to
upgrade earnings expectations "towards the higher end" of the consensus range, which
would put FY16E EBITDA at c£68-69m (CGe: £65.3m). We think uSwitch prospects are
good - beyond energy switching, the tie-up with the Zoopla site should help it grow its
nascent financial services offering, as well as providing a lucrative stream of traffic.
In addition, the group is making continued progress in Property Services, confirming it
has now grown agency membership for 11 consecutive months since the nadir in April
2015.
Valuation
At last night's close, ZPLA trades on 18.5x calendar 2016E EV/EBITDA and 22.9x PER,
having rallied 13.0% in the past week.

Cutting out the middle man. In essence today's acquisition will ultimately lead to less
complexity and more services for Zoopla and PSG's customers. For instance in all but the
smallest UK businesses, agents upload property details to their back office systems before
uploading again to the property portals. Today's acquisition will allow Zoopla to provide
a one stop shop for day to day inventory and CRM management all the way through to
digital marketing
Market leader. PSG provides software to around 8,000 branches (a c.40% market share)
and we understand that the next largest player Reapit has around a 15% market share.
Sticky customers. Customer churn is much lower for PSG than it has been in Zoopla's
recent past, in the year to 31 March 2016 customer retention was more than 97%
Cross selling opportunities. We understand that only around 3,000 of PSG's customers
currently use the Zoopla platform, by providing an end to end solution we expect many the
PSG only customers to join the Zoopla platform over the medium, although do not factor
such cross-selling into our estimates.
Financial highlights. Acquisition consideration £75m (implied 14.7x EBITDA - year to 31
March 16). We have penciled in c.20% EBITDA growth for FY17 and FY18, with 4 months
contribution for Zoopla's FY16
Estimate changes. Our initial take is that consensus EPS will increase by c.3% for FY16
and c.5% in FY17.
